_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Cloverleaf Cold Storage facility located in Sumter, South Carolina provides logistics services for retail customers throughout the Southeast of the USA, including the storage of nonhazardous packaged foods.  We are proud of our safety record and strive to ensure that we design and operate our facility so that hazards are minimized and risks controlled.



We use a refrigeration process to maintain appropriate temperatures at critical control points in our operation.  Anhydrous ammonia, the refrigerant used in this process, is regulated by EPA under 40CFR part 68 and by OSHA under 29CFR 1910.119.  We have specific programs and practices in place for controlling this process to help ensure that a harmful release of ammonia does not occur.  These programs and practices include:

-    Use of recognized good engineering practices in the design, installation and operation of our refrigeration equipment and ensuring this equipment meets applicable codes and standards.

-    Continual assessment of hazards and safeguards in our process, in order to reduce risks.

-    Use of release prevention practices that have been recognized as effective by Federal and State experts.

-    Maintaining preparedness and contingency plans for responding to any emergency that may occur and coordinating these plans with local response agencies.



Using EPA-approved methods and technology, we have analyzed worst-case and alternative scenarios for the unlikely release of ammonia from our Refrigeration Process.  The results of these analyses, including any public or environmental receptors are available upon request to facility management and/or from the US EPA.  



Our PSM and RMP Program focuses on preventing hazardous releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Our equipment and management practices are consistent with OSHA regulations and recognized good engineering practices specified by ASHRAE, ASME and ASTM standards.  In the unlikely event that a release of ammonia were to occur, monitoring devices would

immediately alert us so that quick action can be taken to minimize the impact.  These and other activities are part of our Emergency Response Plan that is coordinated with local Emergency Response agencies.



We are continually seeking ways to improve the safety of our operations.  Consistent with that policy, our facility has been designed to include best practices in safety and environmental protection advancements.  As evidence of this commitment, we completed a process hazard analysis in February 2012 and expect to resolve all recommendations from that analysis by the end of 2012.  Our Process Safety and Risk Management Program and Emergency Response Plan are in place and being used to manage hazards and control risks associated with hazardous materials at our facility, including semi-annual reviews of operating procedures and mechanical integrity practices.  We continually monitor our operations to identify ways to maintain a leadership position within our industry in environmental, health and safety practices.
